triples.name: Free will
triples.relevance: The paper reviews and analyzes competing philosophical perspectives on whether free will exists and how it relates to determinism and moral responsibility.

triples.name: Evolution
triples.relevance: The paper discusses how evolution processes may have given rise to free will in organisms, a central argument in Kevin Mitchell's thesis.

triples.name: Moral responsibility
triples.relevance: The paper examines the philosophical connection between free will and whether humans can be held morally responsible for their actions.

triples.name: Natural selection
triples.relevance: The paper discusses how natural selection packs knowledge into organisms and serves as a basis for the development of decision-making capabilities.

triples.name: Sentience
triples.relevance: The paper argues that sentience is an important ontological category distinct from non-sentient life, and is necessary for understanding free will.

triples.name: Consciousness
triples.relevance: The paper references the 'hard problem' of consciousness as a key unsolved issue related to explaining free will and subjective experience.

triples.name: Determinism
triples.relevance: The paper directly addresses the philosophical debate between determinism and free will, with Sapolsky arguing for determinism and Mitchell arguing against it.

triples.name: Neuroscience
triples.relevance: The paper discusses neuroscience perspectives through the work of Robert Sapolsky, who brings neuroscientific arguments to the free will debate.

triples.name: Quantum mechanics
triples.relevance: Mitchell invokes quantum physics interpretations by Lee Smolin and Clelia Verde to argue that the future is genuinely open, supporting the possibility of free will.
